text: RT @AndrewDesiderio: New: Sen. Angus King, Senate Intel member, tells me they should hold hearings on Trump’s firing of Michael Atkinson.…
Important information for Maine people planning to file for unemployment. Filings over the phone should follow the below call-in schedule: https://t.co/866D1rXTA8

Today in #MaineTogether – first responders, up bright and early in Augusta to thank the medical heroes on the front lines of this fight. We can’t all be there for each other in the usual ways, but Maine people will always find a way to show their support. https://t.co/Aylb0koT3v

Talked with @rscordes at @MaineBiz about the importance of telehealth, the need for increased broadband across the state, and our responsibility to support Maine’s healthcare workers in every way possible. READ: https://t.co/bcsH9m0Cg3

The removal of Michael Atkinson as Inspector General to the Intelligence Community will create a vacuum of professional, honorable and objective judgment in a position explicitly designed to be independent and clear-eyed. My full statement: https://t.co/CciKT3bcBp

Now here’s a #MaineTogether for you – in Aroostook County, a woman is delivering groceries to folks in need via dog sled. Neither pandemic nor snow shall stop Maine people from looking out for one another! https://t.co/MvZXWWkjAz
Last November – a month before the first publicly reported case of coronavirus – I raised the alarm about the decision to shutter this program. Read my full letter: https://t.co/a2uac8SyWt

U.S. leadership on global health is vital, but last year the administration cut a program specifically focused on identifying pandemics. What’s done is done, but America must learn from this mistake and invest in public health. Via @RaineyTime @Emily_Baum https://t.co/DfEC9VYyFj

Constituent service in a time of virus. This awkward meeting is a sign of the times – something we must do to ensure this ends sooner than later. So for now, do what the Governor says, buy carryout from local merchants, and teach your mom to use FaceTime. https://t.co/APAEOebZOS https://t.co/yv8A8waM1A

In the days ahead, I’ll be sharing more examples of #MaineTogether at work – and hope you’ll do so too! We can’t come together in the ways we usually do – but that doesn’t mean the Maine spirit of supporting each other isn’t as strong as ever. We will get through this, together.

In the face of increased unemployment and healthcare needs, our people are ready to take on the circumstances in front of us and make the best of a bad situation. That’s what Maine is all about – we adapt, work hard, and take care of each other. #MaineTogether

My first example of #MaineTogether – Maine’s community colleges are preparing to offer free online training to recently laid-off Maine workers to help bolster our healthcare workforce and increase our readiness for coronavirus. https://t.co/POTwMxhAbC

As coronavirus spreads across our state, I think it’s more important than ever to shine a light on the Maine people who are stepping up to support our communities and take care of our neighbors. That’s why I'm introducing a new hashtag to highlight the best of us: #MaineTogether.

In the days ahead, I’ll keep pushing to make sure our citizens have every opportunity to weather this challenge and come out the other side stronger than ever. This is a challenging time, but we will get through it, together.

This announcement comes hours after I joined a group of Senators urging the Administration to reverse course and administer this aid to our seniors as quickly and efficiently as possible. Now, Maine's seniors will be able to access these vital funds without needless delays. https://t.co/Qa1ojU1TSH

The last thing our seniors should be worried about in the middle of this pandemic is filling out time-consuming, unnecessary paperwork when they need help immediately. I’m glad the IRS will administer these payments the way Congress intended. https://t.co/5CJqBUuUem

This is an awful, harmful decision. As Americans face the most serious public health crisis in a century, we should be doing everything possible to help more of them access lifesaving healthcare. The Administration should reverse course, immediately. https://t.co/3jBRheziPK

Want a quick social distancing activity that will help your community? Today is #CensusDay2020, so take a few minutes to get counted. It’s safe. It’s anonymous. It will help Maine get our fair share of road, school, clinic, and infrastructure funds. https://t.co/jTD8lAZZLd

I know that staying at home can feel like you’re doing nothing – but it’s the most selfless, effective, and patriotic thing you can do right now. Thanks to @GovJanetMills for taking this action to keep Maine people safe. https://t.co/aYpwF01gYI
@RetailMaine No, they are not taxable.

I know Maine people have questions about the direct payments of up to $1,200 passed by Congress last week. As logistics are being finalized for this unprecedented action, the IRS has put together a good resource to answer some of the most common questions: https://t.co/pv08lTYrJd
That is unacceptable. That’s why the Maine Delegation urged DHS to make sure Maine healthcare providers get all the tools they need to win this battle. Full letter here: https://t.co/nTVUcI4LpJ

Maine’s medical professionals are the heroes of our fight against coronavirus, and we need to make sure they have all the personal equipment they need to protect their own health, but per @MEPublicHealth we’re receiving only a fraction of our needed PPE. https://t.co/zgEYJaxAKY

In the @bangordailynews, I highlighted the help that is on the way for Maine’s healthcare providers, workers, students, and small businesses during this challenging time. Resources are available – please know that we will get through this together. https://t.co/EYPK9240c3

Heads up! I’m joining @AARPMaine – along with @GovJanetMills and other Maine leaders – to provide an update on the impacts of coronavirus and our efforts to support Maine people during this crisis. Stream here: https://t.co/fGDDjwgdsY

Coronavirus has drastically impacted our medical professionals, who are working on the front lines of this fight – often at great personal risk – to protect the health of our citizens. On #NationalDoctorsDay, we all express our deepest gratitude to these heroes.

The folks at Abbott Labs in Scarborough have put Maine ingenuity to work and created a new coronavirus test that can give results within minutes, not days. This work will save lives across the globe – our state and the world are grateful for their work. https://t.co/s8KjK1Q3yb

On #VietnamVeteransDay, we express our gratitude to the heroes who served in the Vietnam War. Our hearts are with these veterans and their families always – and particularly in this crisis. Here’s a resource for veterans looking for details on coronavirus: https://t.co/Ga5CqOVemL

An example of Maine people coming together to support one another: Big Top Deli in Brunswick (which creatively turned its front door into a pickup window) is encouraging folks to donate to a local hunger prevention program. Don’t you just love Maine?! https://t.co/V7m4CBaUvL https://t.co/qBfLD2ZpjV

Tom Coburn and I often disagreed but formed a close relationship based upon our shared faith and mutual respect. One thing we did agree on was that the NFL shouldn’t have a tax exemption—and here we are about to go on CNN to make that case. I’m sure going to miss him. https://t.co/rFTeVpNqLg
To all Maine people – please be smart and be safe. We all need to do our part to flatten the curve and protect each other from this awful disease.

Today is an incredibly difficult day for all of Maine; we have lost our first neighbor to coronavirus. Mary and I send our deepest sympathies to this man’s loved ones during this challenging time – our entire state mourns with you.
RT @GovJanetMills: Learn more at: https://t.co/ceA4Q6FHXt 3/3
RT @GovJanetMills: Today I am launching a new online resource, https://t.co/n9e7KBzeJx, to help those looking to lend a hand and encourage…
RT @GovJanetMills: The kindness and generosity of Maine people during this challenging time is nothing short of inspiring. I want to thank…

At 1 p.m., I’ll be joining @MaineCalling (and some of you) to discuss the bipartisan coronavirus response package that passed the Senate last night and will be delivering much-needed help to Maine people in the days ahead. Listen here: https://t.co/e62oeQq9cK
Midnight after the vote. https://t.co/hUQZBoQwYN https://t.co/Ub6nvWFevY

The coronavirus response package that passed the Senate tonight is a clear improvement over the original proposal, and will go a long way to helping people throughout Maine and across the nation weather the daunting threat we face. We’ll get through this, together. My statement: https://t.co/hJDTUazPEx

Nearly half of Maine students rely on free and reduced-priced meals at school to get the nutrition they need – as coronavirus shuts down our schools, we have to make sure that our children aren’t going hungry. https://t.co/3WNZzJDmer
In the face of this unprecedented challenge, it’s critical that we all do what we can to support others. @BillNemitz, as usual, nails it: https://t.co/akoPXecxnU

As coronavirus continues to spread, Maine’s medical professionals must have the essential tools they need to treat their patients and keep themselves safe. Today I joined the Maine delegation to urge the federal government to support our medical providers. https://t.co/b8trVWtVpS

Whether it’s placing a take-out order, buying a gift card, or picking up something to-go, there are things we can all do to make sure these institutions we love are still there when this is all over. I know this is hard, but we will get through this – together.

As we’re all doing our best to socially distance ourselves, Maine’s businesses are hurting – and we need to do everything we can to help support them. Here’s a helpful list of small businesses from across the state and their status during this crisis. https://t.co/JI8GOpbLXb

The coronavirus and the steps we’re taking to combat it are forcing Maine people into new, sometimes uncomfortable situations – and with these new situations comes stress for individuals and families. If you’re struggling, @MaineDHHS has good resources: https://t.co/DAm0JqYalP

Grateful to @USTreasury for their quick response to my bipartisan push with @SenJohnThune and @SteveDaines . This is a unique moment, and we need to find every opportunity to protect the American people and keep our most vulnerable citizens healthy.

IMPORTANT UPDATE: the federal tax filing deadline has been delayed until July 15th. 

If you want to file now, you can. If you need to skip the accountant’s office for the moment to continue social distancing, you have 3 extra months for federal taxes. https://t.co/lvNaQJZ7Tr

We’ve already seen major progress – this week, the Small Business Administration approved a disaster declaration allowing Maine businesses to apply for Economic Injury Disaster Loans. In the days ahead, we’ll create more ways to help small businesses push through this challenge.
Additionally, small businesses can access remote mentoring and disaster resources through SCORE, an SBA partner. This help is available by phone, email, and video. https://t.co/yCCzFth8Ca.
For example: the SBA’s Lender Match tool will connect small businesses with participating SBA-approved lenders within 48 hours to help bridge any short-term gaps. https://t.co/UvVh0YLZL4

The Senate is working on legislation to support American small businesses and workers, but in the meantime, @SBAGov has resources to help Maine businesses weather this tough time. https://t.co/7r0O6fzRtO

Maine’s small businesses are the heartbeat of our state’s economy – and they’re the ones likely to be hit the hardest by the economic slowdown caused by coronavirus. To those business owners: we’re not going to forget about you. Help is on the way. https://t.co/c50UoPT3hz
RT @GovJanetMills: Today @SenatorCollins, @SenAngusKing, @chelliepingree, @RepGolden & I convened a conference call where we discussed a nu…
This is why I’ve joined my colleagues to urge direct cash payments to working Americans. We can’t bail out big corporations while we leave American families in the lurch. https://t.co/dnonhgsnsO

Couldn’t agree more, @bangordailynews: “…above all, targeting money directly to small businesses and individuals, rather than bailouts for large industry, should be the main focus of Congress’ next move.” https://t.co/w7QuNTwbEg
About to dial into @mainecalling to discuss ways to support remote learning. Listen here! https://t.co/YBfPJVFR07

The challenges created by the coronavirus are unlike anything in recent memory – but there are things we can do to mitigate this disease and flatten the curve. In @EllsAmerican, eight simple ways we can all combat coronavirus. https://t.co/cqu2ImPWCo

As the Senate crafts new legislation in the days ahead, I’ll work with my colleagues from both parties to strengthen our fight against coronavirus and give workers and businesses the tools they need to weather this hard time.

This legislation guarantees free COVID-19 testing to all Americans, provides paid leave to workers impacted by the virus, extends unemployment benefits, and creates tax credits to help businesses offer paid leave. This is a good start, but there is more work to do.

Today the Senate passed the Families First Act to provide much-needed support to both our public health infrastructure and the millions of Americans who are facing financial hardship as we work to stop the spread of coronavirus.

This excerpt is particularly important. Director Collins argues that everyone – especially young people – “should be volunteering to engage in the most stringent kind of isolation.” A new form of civic duty, to be sure – but one that is vitally important. https://t.co/g3foV5R1DH

This an excellent piece, where NIH Director Francis Collins plainly lays out the challenges we’re facing right now and the steps we need to take to save lives. If you have the time, it’s worth the read. https://t.co/zTAHKZzA0H

These challenges are unprecedented, but we will get through them – together. Passing this legislation swiftly will help millions of Americans access the services they need to weather these new obstacles.

➡️ Extending unemployement insurance benefits to workers who’ve been displaced
➡️ Directly giving checks to Americans making less than six-figures (a proposal I’m glad to see floated by the Administration)
➡️ Improving telework, telehealth, and educational connectivity

➡️ Providing the CDC with the funding it needs to respond quickly to this pandemic
➡️ Strengthening rural telehealth services
➡️ Increasing funding for Meals on Wheels programs that help address both nutrition and social isolation for vulnerable populations.

The coronavirus has disrupted our healthcare system and economy in unprecedented ways, and we must respond quickly and seriously. Today I urged Senate leaders to adopt a package that will address the health, economic, and social challenges we’re facing. My priorities include: https://t.co/poTLx1kC9D

When Congress is discussing ways to support the economy, we can’t forget working Americans. I’m proud to back this proposal, which would provide a lifeline to families struggling with unexpected expenses or drastically reduced income. https://t.co/dnonhgsnsO

For folks who aren’t sure why social distancing matters, or don't think it applies to them because they're healthy, check out these charts. It’s not just about you – it’s about keeping your family and neighbors healthy. Be smart, and stay home if you can. https://t.co/JH9e1QjemK

To Maine people who might be concerned by the use of the phrase ‘national emergency’, know that it is a legal distinction that expedites and funds a thorough response to this threat. We will get through this, together. Be smart, take care of yourself, and listen to the Maine CDC.

Today’s national emergency declaration is a step in the right direction to prevent coronavirus from spreading, but in order for this to have its full effect, the President needs to put politics aside and lean on the expertise of his leading scientists and public health officials.

From @IgnatiusPost: we’re seeing the consequences of being unprepared for threats that can disrupt our society, yet America is still woefully unprepared for cyberattacks. We need to bolster our defenses – and the @CyberSolarium has ideas on where to start. https://t.co/S0JFndXy0J

This isn't a time to panic – but it is a time for caution. Stay safe, and be smart. If you have concerns you may have coronavirus, please call your doctor, or call the Maine coronavirus hotline at 2-1-1. For additional information, please visit https://t.co/UHWPkipHce.

In light of Maine's first presumptive positive case of #COVID_19, a few important tips to stay healthy and preventing community spread:
➡️If you’re showing symptoms, STAY HOME. 
➡️Practice self-distancing
➡️Telecommute 
➡️Avoid unnecessary travel
➡️Wash your hands https://t.co/QbwfyWHcN8

Maine's first presumptive positive #COVID_19 diagnosis underscores the need for Maine people to take common sense steps to protect themselves and reduce any possible community spread. My full statement: https://t.co/uIWjMeFn14
Happening in ~15 minutes! https://t.co/6QJ21BJzK8

If you’d like to hear more about the Commission’s findings or process, we are about to launch our report at an event moderated by @IgnatiusPost. The event is being livestreamed, and you can watch here: https://t.co/OIYWIHOI3G

One last note: our report is *completely unclassified* because improving cybersecurity can’t just happen behind closed doors in Washington. It requires work from each of us. I hope you’ll give it a read, and urge your elected officials to act on cyber before it’s too late.

These are just a few of our recommendations – and by no means is our list exhaustive. We concluded some debates without reaching a consensus, and in this ever-shifting sphere there will be new challenges to face that we can’t yet imagine. But this is a very good place to start.

➡️We need the American people to be able to stay vigilant, and that starts with helping them understand foreign interference. The government should support digital literacy, civics education, and public awareness of malign foreign efforts.
➡️The team at @CISAGov is doing important work already, and we need to elevate their efforts by giving the agency the authorities and funding it needs to reach its full potential.

➡️Congress should establish a Senate-confirmed National Cyber Director within the executive branch. With cyber touching so many aspects of our lives (and government), we need someone at the highest level who can wrangle all the federal agencies to move the ball forward.

➡️Congress should create House Permanent Select and Senate Select Committees. Right now, cyber responsibility is diluted across committees, creating a sometimes insurmountable obstacle to progress. We can’t let Congressional bureaucracy impede necessary action.

To help enact these layers, we’ve created six pillars of deterrence and more than 75 specific recommendations focused on improving security in both the public and private sectors. Some of our key findings:

There is no silver bullet here, but there may be silver buckshot. America needs to pursue layered cyber deterrence by enhancing our defenses at home, reducing benefits for those who would try to exploit our cyber vulnerabilities, and imposing costs for those who cross the line.

The CSC brought together bipartisan Members of Congress – including my co-chair @RepGallagher, @SenSasse, and @JimLangevin – top executive branch officials, and industry leaders, drawing from the different perspectives we need to face this pressing challenge head on.

To be blunt: we are dangerously insecure in cyberspace, even as we become more reliant on it. Everything from your bank account to your health records to your electricity relies on cyber; but America has serious vulnerabilities that, when exploited, inflict lasting damage.

For a year, the @CyberSolarium has worked to review the threats America faces in cyberspace and provide recommendations on how to address them. Today, we’re releasing our report, which we hope will help guide the country in the years ahead. Read: https://t.co/ViDnPftEuG

Today at 1 p.m., I’ll be joining @MaineCalling (and some of you!) to discuss the @CyberSolarium, which is releasing our report today. Call in with questions about the threats we face and ways we can protect ourselves. Listen here: https://t.co/ogdLfBRq9j
RT @CyberSolarium: For some advance insight and a comprehensive overview of the Cyberspace Solarium Commission’s final report, check out th…
At ~7:40, I’ll join @NewDay to discuss today’s @CyberSolarium report and the Commission’s recommendations to restore deterrence in cyberspace.

As veterans transition from active duty to civilian life, we need to do everything possible to help them adjust. Today, I pressed @DeptofDefense nominees on ways we can improve the transition between the DOD and the VA. https://t.co/tlOt2MsPaP
This morning, I’ll be talking to @Axios about the importance of improving America’s cyber defenses – you can watch LIVE here: https://t.co/cLCJRLk6tq

I got this shot as Mary and I made our way to Alabama for the annual Civil Rights Pilgrimage led by @repjohnlewis. My dad was passionate about two things—history and justice; although long gone, I could feel him beside me this morning. #FPICivilRights
https://t.co/y6lReWnzHZ https://t.co/j1624W1lsk
RT @JohnBoozman: It was a pleasure to join @SenAngusKing on his "Inside Maine" podcast recently to discuss #RuralBroadband. We're working t…
RT @RepGolden: Our bill is common sense: families of fallen servicemembers should have free access to America’s most treasured places: our…
RT @RepGolden: After a constituent came to us with the idea for this legislation, I worked w/ @SenAngusKing to make it a reality. We announ…

In the days ahead, it’s critical to stay informed with verified, official information from experts. For more details about the disease and how to protect yourself and your loved ones, please visit the @CDCgov website: https://t.co/LwblU3cgUd

Today, the Senate passed a much-needed funding bill that will support efforts to diagnose and treat the coronavirus outbreak. At $8.3 billion, this bill empowers health professionals to address the threat we face in order to get this virus contained and controlled.

Gold Star families have made unimaginable sacrifices for our nation, and we should do everything we can to help them heal – including giving them access to our greatest natural treasures free of charge. Not complicated – just the right thing to do. https://t.co/VpUhxUnpFj

If we pass the #RestoreOurParks Act and fund #LWCF today, we’ll be ensuring that in 100 years – long after our names have been forgotten – American families will be able to access our nation’s greatest treasures. This is a moment worth seizing – let’s pass this vital legislation. https://t.co/h6VrIBNzJl

Great news that LIHEAP funding will not be impacted by the coronavirus outbreak…unthinkable that it was even considered in the first place. Subjecting low-income Americans to cold winters without heating is no way to support public health. 
https://t.co/GILhqipCjf
That doesn’t work for anyone, which is why I’ve cosponsored legislation to guarantee five paid sick days to every American. It’s the smart – and right – thing to do.

One of the best ways we can stop the spread of diseases is by allowing workers to stay home when they’re sick – but without paid sick leave, workers living paycheck to paycheck have to choose between spreading an illness or falling behind on bills. https://t.co/Ew0uo6xTQa

The Department of Energy’s FY21 Budget proposal would cut the Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy by nearly 75%. This is just bad policy: how can America lead the clean energy economy of the future if the folks in charge won’t invest in it? https://t.co/JjPGRHZ0um

RT @SenAlexander: Thank you, Senator @MarkWarner, for your leadership alongside @SenRobPortman and @SenAngusKing. 

Let’s get the #RestoreO…
RT @CSIS: "Putin could hire 8,000 hackers for the price of one jet fighter. That's a low-cost way to sow chaos amongst your enemies." - @Se…

Today is the latest of this Administration’s efforts to sabotage the ACA. There are no two-ways about this: the people who support this lawsuit are trying to destroy protections for millions of Americans with pre-existing conditions. 
https://t.co/WIaAyOdULD

Access to affordable broadband is essential in a 21st century economy – but as rural connections lag behind, too many Americans are missing out. In February's #InsideMaine @JohnBoozman and @JRosenworcel join me to discuss ways to bridge the digital divide. https://t.co/cPNXwIJ7xu

Good news: in 2019, Congress approved more than $600 million in funding for rural broadband deployment. 
 
Bad news: misguided rules are preventing too many communities from even applying for these funds.
 
I'm working with a bipartisan group to fix that. https://t.co/RS8gf4X2aJ

The VA’s delayed payments to home care services are seriously hurting Maine healthcare providers and the veterans who rely on them – that’s why I sent a letter to @SecWilkie, pushing the VA to streamline their systems and make sure Maine veterans can get the care they’ve earned. https://t.co/RdZDvedb7H

Craft brewers don’t just make a good drink – they also create thousands of jobs, spur economic growth in rural Maine, and boost all sorts of businesses from tourism to agriculture. It was great to celebrate their success today at the New England Craft Brew Summit – cheers to all! https://t.co/dYE6W0IGli

Our adversaries don’t need to change votes to undermine our elections – they just have to weaken our faith in the results. Over the last several months, the @CyberSolarium has made defending our elections a top priority. My joint op-ed with @SpauldingSez: https://t.co/DK4q4S19mG

A great #InsideMaine focused on how we can bridge the digital divide and help rural communities access the opportunities of the internet, coming to @WGANNews and your Apple podcast feed on Saturday! https://t.co/B4k0RUOqJ8

Funding the battle against coronavirus by taking money from LIHEAP, which helps Maine people afford to heat their homes in the cold of winter, is unconscionable. We’d be robbing Peter to pay Paul — either way, public health would suffer. 

https://t.co/4jyVRgAphn

A great visit to @CM_Healthcare’s new urgent care facility last week, which will soon provide quality, convenient, and affordable preventive healthcare to surrounding communities — delivering on CMH’s mission, and one of my top priorities in the Senate. https://t.co/lVSNM6po7O

The administration has not supported the programs that can help proactively address pandemic threats. I’ve introduced legislation to fix this error in judgment, and will keep working to support appropriate preventive efforts that keep Americans safe and healthy in the long-term.

We shouldn’t have to scramble to react to an epidemic like coronavirus – we should have the infrastructure and expertise in place to face these challenges early on. Unfortunately, we’re moving in the wrong direction. https://t.co/fzK0NZqLVB

Those in recovery should have access to the resources they need to overcome addiction and lead happy, healthy lives. I’m pleased that @USDOL has awarded $6.3m to Maine, which will help people in recovery develop the skills they need to get back on track. https://t.co/GOOS5MNEc0

Reliable access to affordable healthcare is key to community wellbeing. This week, I spoke with Maine people in Lewiston to hear about what’s working, and what isn’t – to promote the prevention mindset. Thanks to all who shared their insights!
https://t.co/2fr12cX5VU

Another exciting development in the Lewiston-Auburn area: Central Maine Medical Center is a top-quality resource for Maine families, and soon CMMC will have a new walk-in Urgent Care center to better serve its community. https://t.co/tPmJq6rNCW

Since @grandroundsinc came to Lewiston, they’ve hired over 400 employees and plan to continue growing their staff over the next 5 years. I’m grateful for a first-hand look at Grand Rounds' new facility, and their commitment to workforce development in central Maine. https://t.co/FePQZi2E9t

Beginning the day in Lewiston with a listening session at @SeniorsPlusOrg, followed by a discussion with the staff at the @ircofme on challenges Maine people face in accessing affordable healthcare. https://t.co/QCHVvrdBGR

I wrapped up a great day at Greenhead Lobster and Pemaquid Mussel Farms – we discussed best ways to open up new markets for Maine seafood, and the role aquaculture plays in the future of Maine’s marine economy. https://t.co/w2NiK1oDYV

Maine’s marine economy is made up of processors, dealers, and fishermen – today I stopped by a few facilities that help deliver fresh seafood from the Maine coast to dinner tables across the globe. I began the day with Maine Coast Sea Vegetables and Maine Shellfish Company. https://t.co/TBKIRr9GAb
RT @slaminsamNCM: Happening Now: Sen. Angus King is at Maine Coast Sea Vegetables in Ellsworth. This is stop one of three as the senator is…

Coronary heart disease is the leading cause of death in America, affecting approximately 88,000 Maine people – but it can be prevented. For #AmericanHeartMonth, let’s raise awareness about the disease and the best ways to keep your heart healthy. https://t.co/xuPjuRKisK

A pandemic disease emerging anywhere in the world is a threat to American public health – that’s why this week, I introduced a bill to create a permanent position on the National Security Council that would be charged with monitoring and preventing global health threats. https://t.co/qylQTLsJow
For too long, our body has willingly abdicated this serious responsibility to the executive. We need to reverse this dangerous trend and ensure that no one person can take us into war.

Today’s bipartisan passage of @TimKaine’s War Powers Resolution wasn’t about one president or one event – it’s about Congress reclaiming its Constitutionally-designated power to declare war. https://t.co/CSbdZ1NH9d

The Constitution makes it clear that Congress holds the power to declare war – but over the last 70 years, we’ve too often abdicated that responsibility. Today I joined @EdHenry to discuss the Senate’s bipartisan effort to reassert our Constitutionally-designated responsibility. https://t.co/KuQRX8Rs3B

It’s wrong for a president – any president – to taint the independence of our judicial system by bending the rules for a political ally. In America, we have one set of laws, and no one is above them – if we abandon that principle, we abandon who we are.

Coronavirus is a serious threat to global health; it’s important to remember the flu also needs to be a concern – with nearly 5,000 cases in Maine this season. I'm working with officials and pressing the administration for updates and answers on both. https://t.co/2TM38tpZhz

We don’t have to choose between a thriving economy or a healthy environment, we can (and must) have both! That’s why I’ve joined a group of Senators to introduce the Clean Economy Act – so America can lead the way into the economy of the future.
https://t.co/rBbWtzauGl

In towns across Maine, the local library is a hub for education, entertainment, and community. Making sure these libraries have the tools they need to serve Maine people is vital, and I stand with them all the way. https://t.co/GcoR0AIv0W

This budget is infuriating – but not surprising. Even as we were rushing through the tax bill (with handwritten edits in the margins), I knew that the next step would be proposed cuts for working people across the nation. And, lo and behold, here we are. https://t.co/evo5i6xQux

If I have one bit of advice for my Senate colleagues, it is this: the truth will come out in all of this, and we will be judged on whether we sought it or sought to avoid it. I sincerely hope that our body can rise to this task, and live up to our commitment to impartial justice.

As we approach today’s votes, my colleagues and I face a stark choice: we can either commit to a fair trial that focuses on getting the truth, or endorse a flawed process that attempts to undermine our work before it’s even begun.
It is more obvious than ever that this is not just a trial in the Senate – it is a trial *of* the Senate.

For weeks, Senator McConnell has been telling everyone who would listen that the Senate’s impeachment process would use the rules that governed the Clinton impeachment – but it is clear today that his assertions were at best misleading, and at worst, a willful bait and switch.
